contentrichtext.text: [[File:Modigliani - Female nude (Iris Tree).jpg|thumb|Iris Tree by [[Amedeo Modigliani|Modigliani]], c. 1916]] '''Iris Tree''' (27 January 1897 â€“ 13 April 1968) was an English poet, actress and artists' model, described as a [[Bohemianism|bohemian]], an [[eccentricity (behaviour)|eccentric]], a [[wit]] and an adventuress. Her parents were actors Sir [[Herbert Beerbohm Tree]] and [[Helen Maud Tree]], and her sisters were actresses [[Felicity Tree|Felicity]] and [[Viola Tree]]. An aunt was author [[Constance Beerbohm]], and her uncles were explorer and author [[Julius Beerbohm]] and [[Caricature|caricaturist]] and [[Parody|parodist]] [[Max Beerbohm]]. Iris Tree was sought after, as a young woman, as an artists' model, being painted by [[Augustus John]], simultaneously by [[Duncan Grant]], [[Vanessa Bell]] and [[Roger Fry]], and sculpted by [[Jacob Epstein]], showing her bobbed hair (she was said to have cut off the rest and left it on a train) that, along with other behaviour, caused much scandal. The sculpture is currently displayed at the [[Tate]] Britain. She was photographed countless times by [[Man Ray]], and ran with [[Nancy Cunard]] for a time, in a set at the Eiffel Tower Restaurant of Rudolph Stulik; and acted alongside [[Diana Cooper]] in the mid-1920s. She had studied at the [[Slade School of Art]]. She contributed verse to the 1917 [[The Sitwells|Sitwell]] [[anthology]] ''Wheels''; her published collections were ''Poems'' (1920) and ''The Traveller and other Poems'' (1927). She married twice. Her first marriage was to [[Curtis Moffat]], a New York artist; [[Ivan Moffat]], the [[screenwriter]], was their son. Her second marriage was to the actor and ex-officer of the [[Austria]]n cavalry, Count [[Count Friedrich von Ledebur|Friedrich von Ledebur-Wicheln]]. They both appear (after their divorce) in the [[Moby Dick (1956 film)|1956 film version]] of ''[[Moby-Dick]]''. She also appears in a cameo, essentially as herself, in [[Federico Fellini]]'s ''[[La Dolce Vita]]''. ==See also== {{portal|Poetry}} * [[Beerbohm family]] ==References== * ''The Rainbow Picnic: A Portrait of Iris Tree'' (1974) [[Daphne Vivian Fielding]] == External links == * {{imdb name|id=0871678|name=Iris Tree}} * [http://www.bris.ac.uk/theatrecollection/beerbohm.html Tree archive at the University of Bristol Theatre Collection], [[University of Bristol]] {{Authority control|VIAF=15620469}} {{Persondata <!-- Metadata: see [[Wikipedia:Persondata]]. --> | NAME = Tree, Iris | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = Artists' model, poet | DATE OF BIRTH = 27 January 1897 | PLACE OF BIRTH = | DATE OF DEATH = 13 April 1968 | PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Tree, Iris}} [[Category:1897 births]] [[Category:1968 deaths]] [[Category:Beerbohm family]] [[Category:English artists' models]] [[Category:English poets]] [[Category:English women writers]] [[Category:English people of Lithuanian descent]] [[Category:English people of German descent]] [[Category:Women poets]] {{UK-poet-stub}} {{england-actor-stub}}
